moves.1. d4 Nf6 2. Bf4 d6 3. Nf3 Nbd7 4. Nbd2: The bishop gives white the opening advantage, since black can't play e5 but white can play e4.
moves.4... c6: Somewhat passive. Black can play c5, and in my view he should.
moves.5. e4: If I can play it, I will. I overlooked Qb6 from black, which would have lead to the famous "poisoned pawn (b2) situation".
moves.5... Qc7: ...but this is a little worse, since the Q pins itself... and this pin will be used!
moves.6. Bc4: The threat is Ng5, aiming to f7. Easily parried, but still a threat that allows me to develop.
moves.6... h6: ? Prevents the N's jump, but is a defensive move, hindering developement. My pieces are all out. Black already suffers a bad position. e5 seems to be his passport to freedom, trying to stand for the pawn with Bd6...
moves.7. e5: I want that diag free of pawns. No matter if d5 (, Bd3).
moves.7... dxe5: Well into my plans. This failure to stop my lsb gives me an idea.
moves.8... Nh5: Sensible: trying to remove the nasty dsb. Now, here I wanted to get. Can you see the tactic shot white has? Can black save from it, how, and how it will become when the dust settles?
moves.9. Bxf7+: If Kd8 (only other legal move), BxNh5 and white is winning.
moves.9... Kxf7 10. e6+: ...it would have been better than this! :-)
